---
title: "Sentence Structure Evaluator"
description: "Sentence Structure evaluator  Check the sentence structure complexity of AI-generated texts aimed at grades 2-6."
---

![][image1]

# Alpha

| [Sentence structure evaluation](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dG4fjW5977vmO96KATWd-PnGOCB_YC_HAIL-J4kFbjk/edit?tab=t.eu7if85ahali#heading=h.qreq1pp9bl3r) ⏵ [Requirements](#requirements) ⏵ [Running this evaluator](#running-the-evaluator) ⏵ [Interpreting results](#interpreting-results) ⏵ |
| :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |

---

This evaluator was developed specifically for AI-generated **informational texts aimed at grades 2–6**.

The evaluation looks at a text, and returns a complexity label of:

- Slightly complex
- Moderately complex
- Very complex
- Exceedingly complex.

You can use the label to help decide if the text meets your needs and expectations.

The evaluator automates the time-consuming analysis of sentence structure as part of defining text complexity. It can be used to help ensure AI-generated texts are sufficiently complex for the grade-level, and that sentence structure complexity progresses appropriately across the year and grades.

### — Why it matters

By understanding what makes a text difficult for a student to read, EdTech companies and educators are better equipped to ensure students get the right text for their needs, along with the right instructional supports.

You can use our evaluation tool to help ensure AI-generated texts are appropriately complex for their intended purposes. For example, the complexity of the texts students work with should increase across the year, and that different levels of complexity are needed from different types of texts. Anchor texts should be rich and complex (and increasingly so across the year). However supplementary texts may be intentionally simpler if they are aimed at scaffolding students’ background knowledge on a topic rather than progressing reading skills.

---

## How it works

This evaluator works by breaking the evaluation of sentence structure into 2 distinct stages:

1. Labeling the sentences of the text as simplex, compound or complex.
2. Assigning a complexity rating to the passage.

It uses an LLM and statistical methods to boost accuracy and cut down on result variability.

---

## Requirements

To run the sentence structure evaluation, you’ll need:

- The [system prompt & user prompt](?tab=t.jsrp2thf4hef#heading=h.x5gnay42dv3q) to **label sentences**.
- The [system prompt & user prompt](?tab=t.jsrp2thf4hef#heading=h.9oyn6vnfz584) to **assign complexity.**\
  You may choose to replace this prompt with a deterministic function.
- A model and temperature setting. We found this to be the most accurate:
  - Model: gpt-4o (specifically `gpt-4o-2024-08-06`)
  - Temperature: 0.5\
    NOTE: We didn’t find meaningful differences in gpt-4o’s performance when varying the temperature in increments of 0.25 between 0 and 1, so you can change this setting without a decrease in accuracy.

---

## Running the evaluator

1. Make an API call to gpt-4o using the [label sentences prompts](?tab=t.jsrp2thf4hef#heading=h.x5gnay42dv3q).\
   This returns a set of statistics included in your text passage.
2. Using the statistics produced in step 1, make another API call to gpt-4o using the prompts that [assign complexity](?tab=t.jsrp2thf4hef#heading=h.9oyn6vnfz584).\
   You can also use a deterministic function instead of an LLM for this step to reduce latency and cost. Here is some [sample Python code](?tab=t.3q8ildx8k2cc).

### — Choosing test passages

As you choose texts to test, keep in mind:

- **Personal data:** Use only anonymous, general-purpose, informational text. Never use student information, real-world personal data, or any content subject to privacy regulations such as FERPA, COPPA, HIPAA, or GDPR.
- **Grade level:** This evaluator was tested on AI-generated informational texts for grades 2–6. It might not be as reliable for texts meant for lower or higher grades.
- **Passage length:** We tested with texts that range between 108 and 640 words. Because we haven’t yet tested on longer texts, we recommend evaluating passages with less than 750 words (about a page and a half).

### — For best results

| Run multiple times We recommend repeating these steps 3 times per text passage to smooth over any errors the LLM might make.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| **Run sentence labeling and complexity assignment in separate prompts** We split the evaluation into two stages because the evaluator can get confused when the stages are combined.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| **Apply a voting mechanism** In the sentence labeling task, we found that the same LLM can sometimes differ in its labeling across API calls. For example, when asked to categorize the sentence:  _The girl—a freckle-faced brunette, about ten years old, in a striped dress and sandals—bought an ice cream cone and took it to the park._ An LLM might incorrectly label this sentence as “basic complex” (one independent and one dependent clause). In another run with the LLM, it might label this sentence as simple (the correct categorization [per MLA](https://style.mla.org/types-of-sentences/)). Because LLMs can return different results for the same input, even when their temperature settings are low, we recommend running the evaluation 3 times for each input and treating each complexity rating as a “vote” towards the true rating.  You may want to try a higher number of runs for even greater confidence in the LLM’s output. |

---

## Interpreting results

### — What you’ll see

The feedback includes a complexity score for each passage, and an explanation about why the passage was given this rating based on the [Sentence Structure rubric](?tab=t.xo4gppfrmy74). This takes the form of a JSON object with two keys: **answer** and **reasoning**. For example:

```json
{
answer: slightly_complex
reasoning: The text consists entirely of simple sentences, with 100% of the sentences being simple. According to the rubric, a text is Slightly Complex if it has at least 50% simple sentences and no advanced complex sentences. Since the text has 100% simple sentences and no advanced complex sentences, it fits the criteria for Slightly Complex.
}
```

### — How to use the information

Check out the [rubric](?tab=t.xo4gppfrmy74) for details of how each result is measured and what it means. Also take a look at the [evaluator accuracy](?tab=t.at2es4epmge5) to see where the evaluator is most accurate and most likely to make mistakes.

The information provided by the Sentence Structure evaluator can be combined with quantitative measures and feedback from other evaluators used in a variety of ways. For example:

#### **Curriculum and assessment creators**

- Ensure AI generated texts are appropriately complex for their intended use.
- Provide guidance on instructional focus for educators.
- Provide instructional focus guidance on where and why texts may pose challenges to students.

#### **EdTech developers**

- Ensure the complexity of texts increases appropriately during a year and across grades.
- Ensure Ai-generated texts meet the complexity requirements expected by educators.

(i) in general the complexity should go up over the school year, and separately, (ii) the complexity should be customized to the instructional needs of the educator (e.g. is the educator putting a particular focus on vocab with this text? or on the syntax/sentence structure? or something else?)

### — Current limitations

Keep in mind these limitations for the current version of this evaluator.

- Use your judgement when interpreting the results especially if you are using them to inform curriculum development, educational interventions, or product design.
- Some variability is inherent in LLM outputs. Occasional inconsistencies in sentence labeling or complexity scoring may occur across runs.
- The evaluator was tested on passages ranging from approximately 100 to 640 words. Performance on very short texts (under 100 words), long texts (over 750 words) or multi-topic passages has not been formally validated.
- The validation dataset includes few examples of ‘exceedingly complex’ sentence structures and highly intricate academic texts may not be accurately evaluated.
